conclusion: The problem involves an ideal gas undergoing a state change from A to B to C, with the temperature at state A given as 27Â°C.
The ideal gas law \( PV = nRT \) will be used to relate the states of the gas.
From the figure, at state A, \( P_A = 3 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \) and \( V_A = 1 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).
From the figure, at state C, \( P_C = 1 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa} \) and \( V_C = 3 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).

premise: The temperature at state A is given as \( T_A = 27^\circ \text{C} = 273 + 27 = 300 \, \text{K} \).
conclusion: The temperature at state A is \( T_A = 300 \, \text{K} \).

premise: The ideal gas law relates the states: \( \frac{P_A V_A}{T_A} = \frac{P_C V_C}{T_C} \).
conclusion: The relationship \( T_C = \frac{P_C V_C T_A}{P_A V_A} \) can be derived.

premise: Substitute the values \( P_A = 3 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa}, V_A = 1 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3, T_A = 300 \, \text{K}, P_C = 1 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa}, V_C = 3 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \) into \( T_C = \frac{P_C V_C T_A}{P_A V_A} \).
The calculation \( T_C = 300 \, \text{K} \) matches the given conditions and the ideal gas law.
conclusion: The final temperature of the gas at state C is \( T_C = 300 \, \text{K} \).
